questions.text: Which one of the following tests has the highest chance of detecting HIV infection in a blood donor during the window period?

options.label: A
options.text: Demonstration of antibody to HIV by ELISA

questions.explanation:
Solution:

P24 antigen detection The " window period " refers to the maximum amount of time it may take for a person's body to create HIV antibodies after HIV infection. Usually, the ELISA test turns positive after 3-6 months of infection. The p24 antigen test can detect the p24 protein on average 10 to 14 days after infection with HIV . One drawback of this test is that levels of the p24 protein peak at around three to four weeks after exposure to HIV and are usually not detectable after five to six weeks (and sometimes even earlier) corresponding with the development of antip24 antibodies.

Highyeild:

HIGH YIELDING:- A positive p24 test means that someone is HIV-positive. However, a negative p24 test can mean three things: The person is HIV-negative The person is HIV-positive but the test could not detect the p24 protein because the person was infected more than four to six weeks earlier The levels of the p24 antigen are too low to be detectable with current technologies. The HIV NAAT test is a very sensitive test designed to detect HIV RNA in blood. The NAAT test is able to detect HIV RNA as early as 7 to 14 days after infection with HIV. Unlike the p24 test, the NAT test will always give a positive result as long as there is HIV in someone's blood.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D are not the most sensitive tests during the window period among the following.

questions.text: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). By damaging your immune system, HIV interferes with your body's ability to fight infection and disease. Most common pulmonary manifestation of AIDS:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumonia Pulmonary disease is one of the most frequent complications of HIV infection. The most common manifestation of pulmonary disease is pneumonia . 3 of the 10 most common AIDS-defining illnesses are recurrent bacterial pneumonia, tuberculosis , and pneumonia due to the unicellular fungus jiroveci. Other major causes of pulmonary infiltrates include other mycobacterial infections fungal infections, nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis, KS, and lymphoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are not the most common pulmonary manifestations in AIDS.

questions.text: Pneumocystis carinii is a cause of diffuse pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts. Even in fatal cases, the organism and the disease remain localized to the lung. Pneumonia rarely, if ever, occurs in healthy individuals. All are seen with Pneumocystis carinii in AIDS except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meningitis In addition to pneumonia, a number of other clinical problems have been reported in HIV-infected patients as a result of infection with P. jiroveci. Otic involvement may be seen as a primary infection , presenting as a polypoid mass involving the external auditory canal. In patients receiving aerosolized pentamidine for prophylaxis against PCP, one may see a variety of extrapulmonary manifestations of P. jiroveci. These include ophthalmic lesions of the choroid , a necrotizing vasculitis that resembles Buerger's disease , bone marrow hypoplasia , and intestinal obstruction. Other organs that have been involved include lymph nodes, spleen, liver, kidney, pancreas, pericardium, heart, thyroid, and adrenals.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- So, Options A, B, and C can present in pneumocystis infection in AIDS.

questions.text: Acute HIV infection is the earliest stage of HIV infection, and it generally develops within 2 to 4 weeks after infection with HIV. All are seen in acute HIV syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumonia Findings in Acute HIV syndrome are: Fever Lymphadenopathy Pharyngitis Headache Arthralgias Myalgias Weight loss Nausea/vomiting/diarrhea Meningitis Encephalitis Peripheral neuropathy Myelopathy Erythematous maculopapular rash Mucocutaneous ulceration Options A, C, and D are present in acute HIV syndrome.

questions.text: During the routine screening of blood prior to donation, a virus with the structure shown below is detected. Among the following options which group does the virus belong to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lentiviridae The HIV virus is the etiological agent of AIDS , it belongs to the family of retroviruses and subfamily - lentiviruses As seen in the structure, The virus is composed of a capsid core that contains the genetic material that has been surrounded by a protein envelope. The protein envelope has many spikes of the glycoprotein .

Highyeild:

The outer part of the glycoprotein called gp120 is attached to the gp41 which is the inner part of the glycoprotein . The genome of HIV contains two helices of RNA molecules in folded form . The enzymes reverse transcriptase is present which is responsible for the conversion of the RNA to form the DNA. There is another enzyme called integrase which helps the viral genome to incorporate in the host cell.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A , Flaviviridae is a family of positive , single-stranded, enveloped RNA viruses. It includes arthropod-borne viruses eg yellow fever, JE, dengue virus, etc Option: B. Picornaviruses are a group of related non-enveloped RNA viruses . Eg enterovirus Option: D. It includes the hepatitis B virus which is a DNA virus

questions.text: A 27-year-old HIV-positive female is pregnant and presents at 16 weeks of gestation for her antenatal follow-up. She is on regular ART and is compliant with her medication. Her last CD4 count done 2 weeks ago is 450 cells/mm3 and her viral RNA level is 600 copies/ml. Based on these reports, which of the following statements is incorrect regarding her pregnancy and risk of transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum risk of transmission is during delivery and birth of the baby

options.label: B
options.text: She has a low risk of transmission to the fetus as viral RNA levels are <1000 copies/ml

options.label: C
options.text: Prolonged interval between membrane rupture and delivery increases the risk of transmission

options.label: D
options.text: All the above statements are true.

questions.correct_answer: D. All the above statements are true.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above statements are true. HIV can be transmitted from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy , during delivery, or by breastfeeding Among all mother-to-child transmissions of HIV,23-30% occurred before birth, 50-65% occurred during birth and 12-20% occurred via breastfeeding. Therefore, the maximum risk is during delivery It is very unlikely that mother–to–child transmission will occur if the mother's level of plasma viremia is < 1000 copies of HIV RNA/ml and extremely unlikely if the level is undetectable i.e. < 50 copies/ml. Therefore, this patient who has 600 copies /ml is at low risk for transmission Hence all the above options are true

questions.text: A 28-year-old male has indulged in unsafe sexual practices and has come for an HIV antibody test. He also says that he is an iv drug abuser and frequently shares needles. Which of the following exposures has the highest risk of acquiring HIV?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blood transfusion As per this table, the highest risk is by blood transfusion - 9250 per 10000 exposures. It is estimated that >90% of individuals exposed to HIV-contaminated blood products become infected. Transfusions of whole blood, packed blood cells, platelets, leucocytes, and plasma are all capable of transmitting HIV

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . The risk is 138 per 10000 exposures. Option: C. Risk is 63 per 10000 exposures Option: D. The risk is 23 per 10000 exposures

Extraedge:

Hyperimmune gamma globulin, hepatitis B immunoglobulin, plasma-derived Hep B vaccine, and Rh immune globulin have not been associated with the transmission of HIV infection. The procedures involved in processing these products are either inactive or remove the virus.

questions.text: Identify the structures labeled a, b, and c in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-capsid b –RNA c-gp120 The HIV virion is ~100 m in diameter. Its innermost region consists of a cone-shaped core that includes two copies of the (positive sense) ssNA genome, the enzymes reverse transcriptase, integrase, and protease, some minor proteins, and the major core protein. The genome of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) encodes 8 viral proteins playing essential roles during the HIV life cycle Embedded within this membrane are the viral glycoproteins; the gp120 surface glycoprotein and the gp41 transmembrane glycoprotein. Each envelope subunit displays on the virion surface as a trimer of the outer envelope glycoprotein gp120, non-covalently linked to a trimer of gp41 , the transmembrane protein that anchors this glycoprotein complex to the surface of the virion.

Extraedge:

The virus is enveloped with a lipid bilayer derived from the host cell , thus incorporating proteins found in the host membrane, such as the major histocompatibility (MHC) molecules CD44 and lymphocyte function-associated antigen 1 (LFA-1).

questions.text: The structural proteins of HIV are encoded by various important genes. Match the following genes of the HIV genome and their functions: Choose the correct answer from below-given code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-2 B-1 C-4 D-3 Organization of the genome of the HIV provirus together with a summary description of its 9 genes encoding 15 proteins. (Reproduced with permission from WC Greene et al: Charting HIV's remarkable voyage through the cell: Basic science as a passport to future therapy. Nat Med 8:673, 2002.) The functions can be summarized as given in the table below:- GENE FUNCTION Tat Nef Rev Vif Increases activity of RNA polymerase and leads to elongation of viral genome Decreases expression of MHC-1 Inhibits RNA splicing Inhibits RNA splicing Vpr Vpu Gag Virion release Encodes for the matrix (p17) and capsid (p24 Pol Encodes for revere transcriptase, integrase and protease Env Encodes for gp120 and gp41

Extraedge:

The major difference between genomes of HIV1 and 2 is that HIV-2 lacks vpu gene and has a vpx gene not contained in HIV-1

questions.text: The presence of which of the following leads to an individual being highly resistant to acquiring HIV infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CCR5 Delta32 mutation A 32-bp deletion (delta32) in the coding region of CCR5 contributes to the resistance to CCR5 by R5 strains of HIV Studies in large cohorts demonstrated that individuals homozygous for the CCR5 delta 32 mutation lack CCR5 surface expression and are highly resistant to acquiring infection The distribution of CCR5 delta 32 mutation is population specific and is seen usually seen in individuals of European ancestry

Highyeild:

ApoE -associated with HIV-associated dementia ApoL1/MYH9 -increased risk for HIV nephropathy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . It is associated with a higher risk of abacavir associated hypersensitivity and slower progression to AIDS Option: C . It is associated with faster progression to AIDS and higher viral load Option D- It is associated with slower progression to AIDS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who indulged in unsafe sexual practices one week ago now reports to the medicine OPD for an HIV antibody test. The treating physician explains to him that the HIV antibody test may be false negative as he is in the window period and antibodies may not be detectable in blood. What is the usual time taken for seroconversion in patients infected with HIV?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3-6 weeks Antibodies to HIV usually appear within 3-6 weeks and almost invariably within 12 weeks. These are non-neutralizing antibodies and are capable of mediating antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity(ADCC) Neutralizing antibodies appear by 3 months Order of appearance of antibodies is:- Antibodies to gp41 ⬇️ Antibodies to p24(gag) ⬇️ Antibodies to gp120

questions.text: A 38-year-old male, presents with a history of unexplained fever for the last 3 weeks. He also complains of sore throat, anorexia, and myalgia. Since the last 2 days, he has also noted a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash over his extremities. On examination, his BMI-16 kg/m2, and cervical lymphadenopathy are non-matted. The rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute HIV syndrome This is a typical case scenario of acute HIV syndrome. The patient has the below symptoms /signs which favor the diagnosis of acute HIV syndrome:- -Fever -Pharyngitis (he gives h/o sore throat) -Lymphadenopathy -Myalgias -Anorexia -Weight loss(BMI is 16 kg/m2) -Erythematous maculopapular rash -50-70% of individuals with HIV infection experience an acute clinical syndrome 3-6 weeks after primary infection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. pulmonary tuberculosis can present with anorexia, fever, weight loss but it will have a history of cough with expectoration, hemoptysis, Option: B. It presents in younger age groups with fever, polyarthritis, heart murmur, chorea, raised ESR, etc. These features are not seen in this patient. lymphadenopathy is not a feature of rheumatic fever. Option: D. The rash is classical erythema migrans (with central clearing ) and not diffuse erythematous as seen in this patient. Other features which this patient has can be a feature of Lymes disease too.

questions.text: A 45 year old truck driver who has indulged in unsafe sexual practices presents with a history of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following can be considered as a differential diagnosis for this set of symptoms
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both of the above The differential diagnosis to be considered in this case are Acute HIV infection Infectious mononucleosis Acute HIV infection is the earliest stage of HIV infection , and it generally develops within 3-6 weeks after infection with HIV. During this time, some people have flu-like symptoms, such as fever, headache, and Rash. In the acute stage of infection , HIV multiplies rapidly and spreads throughout the body. The virus attacks and destroys the CD4 cells ( CD4 T lymphocyte ) of the immune system. A close differential is acute infectious mononucleosis Infectious mononucleosis also known as glandular fever , is an infection usually caused by the Epstein–Barr virus . It can also present with fever, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The most prominent sign of the disease is often pharyngitis , which is frequently accompanied by enlarged tonsils with pus —an exudate similar to that seen in cases of strep throat. In about 50% of cases, small reddish-purple spots called petechiae can be seen on the roof of the mouth

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage 2 CDC Staging of HIV:- 2014 CDC Case Definition for HIV Infection Among Adolescents and Adults Stage CD4 Count CD4 % Clinical Evidence Stage0 Early HIV Infection Stage1 2500 cells/mm 3 ≥26 No No AIDS-defining condition Stage2 200-499 cells/mm³ 14-25 No AIDS-defining condition Stage 3 200-499 cells/mm³ <14 or Documentation of AIDS-defining condition Stage unknown No data No data and No information on the presence of AIDS-defining conditions *Use CD4 percentage only if no data available for CD4 count Therefore, this patient has a CD4 count of 350 cells with NO other AIDS-defining illnesses and hence He is stage 2

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with a history of unexplained weight loss and loss of appetite for the last 2 -3 months. He also feels excessively fatigued and complains of chronic diarrhea. His BMI is 14.2kg/m2. Oral candidiasis. He also has lesions as shown in the image below which are painless and non pruritic. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HHV-8 The patient complains of anorexia, and weight loss along with associated oral candidiasis, and chronic diarrhea. All these features point to a diagnosis of HIV-AIDS. The image shows multiple reddish-purple vascular nodules suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma The causative organism is Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8). Kaposi sarcoma is a multicentric neoplasm consisting of multiple vascular nodules appearing in the skin, mucus membranes, and viscera. It can occur even in the presence of a normal CD4 count Lesions often appear in sun-exposed areas, particularly the tip of the nose, and have a propensity to occur in areas of trauma ( Koerner phenomenon )

Highyeild:

Management of AIDS-Associated Kaposi's Sarcoma Observation and optimization of antiretroviral therapy Single or limited number of lesions ● Radiation ● Intralesional vinblastine ● Cryotherapy Extensive disease ● Initial therapy ● Interferon a (if CD4+ T cells >150/µL) ● Liposomal daunorubicin ● Subsequent therapy ● Liposomal doxorubicin ● Paclitaxel Combination chemotherapy with low-dose doxorubicin, bleomycin, and vinblastine (ABV) Targeted radiation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Lichen plans is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease with purple , polygonal , planar , pruritic papules and plaques usual over flexor aspect Option: B. It causes development of painful vesicular lesions along a dermatome. Option: D. EBV does not cause these cutaneous manifestations

questions.text: A 45-year male comes to the OPD for a HIV test. A 4th generation ELISA test is performed which tests HIV-1 and 2 antibodies and p-24 antibodies. It is found to be positive. As per the CDC recommendation, what is the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Collect sputum for AFB and start ART

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform HIV 1 / 2 antibody differentiation test
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perform HIV 1 / 2 antibody differentiation test The FLOWCHART below shows the algorithm for HIV testing as suggested by CDC As per this algorithm If the initial ELISA test (which detects Antibodies to HIV 1 and 2 and antibodies against p24) is positive next step will be to perform an HIV 1 or HIV 2 specific antibody immunoassay If this antibody immunoassay test is negative or indeterminate- Further testing by HIV NAT can be done Western blot is not a part of the CDC testing algorithm

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. The diagnosis has to be confirmed and a single ELISA positive test should not be used to start treatment Option: B. There is no requirement to repeat a positive ELISA test and instead antibody immunoassay tests should be done. Option: D. As per the CDC algorithm NAT test is used when the confirmatory immunoassay is negative or indeterminate.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female, a known HIV patient presents for a routine follow-up. Her CD4 count is 320 cells/mm3. Which of the following malignancies is NOT a feature of HIV-AIDS?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HHV-associated invasive cervical carcinoma Invasive cervical carcinoma is caused by Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and not human herpes virus (HHV) Evidence of infection with HPV associated with intraepithelial dysplasia of cervix or anus is approximately twice as common in HIV patients as compared to the general population. It can progress to invasive cervical carcinoma Therefore, comprehensive gynecological and rectal examination including a pap smear is indicated at initial evaluation and 6 months later for all patients with HIV infection If both these examinations are negative , then the patient should be followed up with yearly examinations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . It accounts for 60% of cases of lymphoma in HIV and majority of these are DLBCL Option: C . it is seen when CD4<50 cells/mm3 . It is associated with a poor prognosis

Extraedge:

Lymphoproliferative diseases associated with HIV infection Lymphoproliferative Disorders Strongly Associated with HIV Infection. Tumor Type Key Immunohistochemical and Molecular Diagnostic Findings Unique Features in Patients with HIV Diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma* CD20+, may have c-myc translocation Is the most common lymphoma in patients with HIV; may have CNS involvement Burkitt's lymphoma* CD20+, CD10+, c-myc translocation Immunoblastic morphologic features may be noted AIDS-related primary CNS lymphoma* CD20+, EBV+ Generally occurs in patients with CD4+ counts <100 cells per microliter; concurrent CNS infections may be observed; median patient age is less than that for primary CNS lym- phoma in the general population Primary effusion lymphomas CD20-, KSHV+, EBV+ (in approximately 80% of cases) Was originally described as an effusion lymphoma; other nodal and extranodal presentations are possible; concurrent Kaposi's sarcoma is common Plasmablastic lymphoma* KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease KSHV+, lambda-restricted plasmablasts; a proportion of infected cells are viral interleukin-6+ Features include weight loss, night sweats, fever, anemia, hypo- albuminemia, thrombocytopenia; patients have elevated levels of circulating viral interleukin-6, human interleukin-6, and other cytokines and an increased KSHV viral load Classic Hodgkin's lymphoma Often EBV+, Reed-Sternberg cells Extranodal disease is frequently seen in patients with HIV, in- cluding presentations of bone-only disease; median age is higher than that for Hodgkin's lymphoma in the general population This lymphoma is generally considered AIDS-defining. CNS denotes the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient is being started on Abacavir as a part of his ART regimen. Which of the following tests must be carried out prior to initiation of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Testing for HLA B 5701 Abacavir is a NRTI used in the treatment of HIV. There is an increased risk of hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir in patients who are HLA B5701 positive. Hence testing must be done prior to the initiation of the drug.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female has been newly diagnosed as HIV positive. All the following test form a part of the initial evaluation of this patient EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-CMV antibody titer Anti-CMV antibody tire is not a part of the initial evaluation of the patient with HIV infection. Also, STD screening for organisms like gonococci, chlamydia, syphilis and trichomonas must be done

Extraedge:

Initial Evaluation of the Patient with HIV Infection History and physical examination Routine chemistry and hematology AST, ALT, alkaline phosphatase, direct and indirect bilirubin Lipid profile and fasting glucose CD4+ T lymphocyte count Plasma HIV RNA level HIV resistance testing HLA-B5701 screening RPR or VDRL test Anti-Toxoplasma antibody titer Urinalysis PPD skin test or IFN-y release assay Mini-Mental Status Examination Serologies for hepatitis A, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C Immunization with pneumococcal polysaccharide; influenza; HPV as indicated Immunization with hepatitis A and hepatitis B if seronegative Counseling regarding natural history and transmission Help contacting others who might be infected

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with unexplained fever, anorexia, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy for the last 1 month. He gives a history of unsafe sexual practices. Acute HIV syndrome is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice in this case for diagnosis of HIV infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

P24 antigen capture assay During the initial window period, antibodies against HIV 1/2 may not be detectable. Therefore, the p24 antigen capture assay has its greatest use as a screening test for HIV infection in patients suspected of having acute HIV syndrome. High levels of p24 antigen are present prior to the development of antibodies Testing for HIV RNA levels is another feasible option as it becomes positive ~10 days after infection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . This test will be negative in early acute hiv as antibody formation has not yet occurred Option: C . B lood culture is not employed for diagnosis of HIV Option: D. I t is not suitable for HIV detection during window period and it is a confirmatory and not a screening test.
